description: From Middle English attachen, from Old French atachier, variant of estachier (“bind”), derived from estache (“stick”), from Frankish *stakkā, *stakō (“stick”), from Proto-Germanic *stakô (“pole, bar, stick, stake”). Doublet of attack. More at stake, stack.

verbs.description: attach (third-person singular simple present attaches, present participle attaching, simple past and past participle attached)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fasten, to join to (literally and figuratively).
examples: Synonyms: connect, annex, affix, unite; see also Thesaurus:join
Antonyms: detach, unfasten, disengage, separate; see also Thesaurus:disconnect
You need to attach the carabiner to your harness.
An officer is attached to a certain regiment, company, or ship.
Synonyms: cling, stick; see also Thesaurus:adhere

entries.meaning: To come into legal operation in connection with anything; to vest.
To win the heart of; to connect by ties of love or self-interest; to attract; to fasten or bind by moral influence; with to.
examples: attached to a friend; attaching others to us by wealth or flattery

entries.meaning: To connect, in a figurative sense; to ascribe or attribute; to affix; with to.
examples: to attach great importance to a particular circumstance

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To take, seize, or lay hold of.

examples: The earl marshal attached Gloucester for high treason.
